1065319272619130881.text:
Here's an ELI5 for the exchange vulnerability I Tweeted about last night, discovered by @levelk_io.

Basically, when an exchange processes a withdrawal to an Ethereum address, that address might be a smart contract. That smart contract might have a default function that uses gas.

1019327752032391168.text: Filecoin and other DSNs need you to do a proof of replication (PoR) of files. It's simple to check if someone has a file. Proving there are actually 3 replicas and not just one compressed file pretending to be 3, is not. Especially if the attacker has ASICs. Thus the work on PIEs

1017778014841602048.text: How Jens Groth fits in with the wider work in zero knowledge proofs. Two main points: 1) Reduce communication complexity when proving to Log(N) based on discrete log (BCCPG16) and 2) How to prove cryptographic languages using pairing based cryptography (Groth-Sahi06)pic.twitter.com/qcEygWW0Gf

1085860526926647296.text: Regarding option 2, I would actually argue that we should be MORE CONSERVATIVE and require that at least 5000 gas be available (instead of 2300), to prevent reentrancies not just in transfer()/send(), but also in hypothetical code like  `call.gas(4999)()`.

1085549793252986882.text:
My two favorite proposals for fixing EIP-1283 so far (both don't modify the semantics of existing contracts):
1. Don't modify SSTORE at all. Make a new opcode SSTORE2 that implements EIP-1283 gas metering.
2. Any SSTORE with less than 2300 gas available causes revert.
